The moon on Karwa Chauth often rises late, following a graceful cosmic rhythm. This timing aligns with its orbital path, its position above, and our place on Earth.
Karwa Chauth is observed on the fourth day (Chaturthi) of the moon's waning phase (Krishna Paksha). Just days after the full moon, it rises later in the evening.
The moon rises about 50 minutes later daily, so by the fourth waning day, moonrise shifts much later compared to the full moon night.
Your exact latitude and longitude dictate when the moon rises, which is why its timing varies between different cities.
